sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• use lowest effective dose for shortest possible duration
  • after observing initial response, adjust dose and frequency to meet individual patient's needs
  • Osteoarthritis: 3000 mg ORALLY daily in 2 to 3 divided doses
  • Rheumatoid arthritis: 3000 mg ORALLY daily in 2 to 3 divided doses

sub.title: Pediatric Dosing
sub.mono: safety and efficacy not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Dose Adjustments
sub.mono: geriatrics: lower dosages may be required for elderly patients

2.title: Black Box Warning
2.mono:
Oral (Tablet)
NSAIDs may cause an increased risk of serious cardiovascular thrombotic events, myocardial infarction, and stroke, which can be fatal. This risk may be increased in patients with cardiovascular disease or risk factors for cardiovascular disease. Salsalate is contraindicated for the treatment of perioperative pain in the setting of CABG surgery. NSAIDs can also cause an increased risk of serious gastrointestinal adverse events especially in the elderly, including bleeding, ulceration, and perforation of the stomach or intestines, which can be fatal.

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• asthma, urticaria, or allergic-type reaction following aspirin or other NSAID administration; severe anaphylactic-like reactions have been reported, including rare fatalities
  • CABG surgery, treatment of perioperative pain
  • hypersensitivity to salsalate

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• cardiovascular thrombotic events; myocardial infarction, stroke, and fatalities have been reported; risk may increase with duration of use
  • cardiovascular disease, known or risk factors for; increased risk of serious cardiovascular thrombotic events, myocardial infarction, and stroke
  • elderly; increased risk of serious gastrointestinal adverse events (bleeding, ulceration, perforation of stomach or intestines) that can occur at any time and without warning; increased risk of renal toxicity or injury
  • gastrointestinal adverse events; ulceration, bleeding, or perforation of stomach or intestines, potentially fatal may occur without warning; increased risk with smoking, alcohol use, poor general health status, or with concurrent use of aspirin, corticosteroids, or anticoagulants; monitoring recommended
  • anaphylactoid reactions and angioedema have occurred
  • aspirin triad (bronchospasm in asthmatic patients with rhinitis, with or without nasal polyps following aspirin or NSAID administration); risk of severe, potentially fatal bronchospasm; use not recommended
  • asthma, preexisting; risk of severe and potentially fatal bronchospasm
  • chicken pox, influenza, or flu-like symptoms; salsalate is structurally related to aspirin; potential to increase risk of Reye's syndrome; not recommended
  • coagulation disorders or concomitant use of anticoagulation agents; may be adversely affected by inhibition of platelet aggregation; monitoring recommended
  • extended duration of therapy; increased risk of potentially fatal gastrointestinal bleeding, ulceration, or perforation that may occur without warning; increased risk of renal papillary necrosis and other renal injury
  • fluid retention and edema have been reported
  • gastrointestinal bleeding, history; increased risk of ulceration or perforation of stomach or intestines, potentially fatal; monitoring recommended
  • heart failure; edema and fluid retention have been reported; increased risk of renal toxicity or injury
  • hepatic dysfunction; increased risk of renal toxicity and liver injury
  • hepatic reactions, including liver enzyme abnormalities, jaundice, fatal fulminant hepatitis, liver necrosis, and hepatic failure have been reported; monitoring recommended; discontinue use with signs or symptoms, or systemic evidence of hepatic reactions
  • hypertension; new onset or exacerbation may occur; use thiazides and loop diuretics may also be less effective when taking NSAIDs;
  • peptic ulcer disease, history; increased risk of bleeding, or perforation of stomach or intestines, potentially fatal; monitoring recommended
  • platelet aggregation inhibition occurs; may result in prolonged bleeding time
  • renal disease, advanced; use is not recommended
  • renal impairment; increased risk of renal toxicity or injury; monitoring recommended
  • renal papillary necrosis and other renal injury may occur; increased risk with concurrent use of diuretics and ACE inhibitors; monitoring recommended; consider discontinuing therapy
  • skin reactions; potentially fatal adverse events including exfoliative dermatitis, Stevens Johnson syndrome, and toxic epidermal necrolysis may occur; discontinue use with first appearance of rash or other sign
  • report suspected adverse reactions to the US Food and Drug Administration at 1-800-FDA-1088 or www.fda.gov/medwatch

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono:
• AAP: Drugs that have been associated with significant effects on some nursing infants and should be given to nursing mothers with caution.
  • Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Rash
  • Gastrointestinal:Nausea
  • Neurologic:Vertigo
  • Otic:Hearing disorder, Tinnitus
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Hypertension, Myocardial infarction
  • Dermatologic:Scaling eczema, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, Toxic epidermal necrolysis
  • Gastrointestinal:Gastrointestinal hemorrhage (1% to 4%), Gastrointestinal perforation (1% to 4%), Gastrointestinal ulcer (1% to 4%), Inflammatory disorder of digestive tract (1% to 4%)
  • Hematologic:Anemia, Blood coagulation disorder, Thrombotic tendency observations
  • Hepatic:Increased liver function test (up to 15%), Jaundice, Liver failure
  • Immunologic:Anaphylactoid reaction
  • Neurologic:Cerebrovascular accident
  • Renal:Acute renal failure, Chronic renal failure, Exacerbation

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Salsalate is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID). The anti-inflammatory property may be attributed to its ability to inhibit prostaglandin synthesis.

3.title: Excretion
3.mono:
• Renal: about 13%
  • Dialyzable: yes (hemodialysis), in extreme cases; yes (peritoneal dialysis), in extreme cases

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• decreased painful/swollen joints, range of motion, reduced early morning stiffness
  • CBC, chemistry profile, blood pressure, fecal occult blood test, liver function; after initiation of NSAID therapy and every 6-12 months thereafter, more frequently in patients at risk for hepatic, renal, cardiac, or gastrointestinal toxicity (eg, age greater than 60 years, high-dose NSAID therapy, concurrent corticosteroids or anticoagulants, history of cardiac, renal, or hepatic disease)
  • renal function
  • signs and symptoms of skin reaction
  • urinary pH; regularly
  • plasma salicylic acid: periodically during long-term therapy

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Warn patients that due to risk of Reye's syndrome, drug should not be used in children without healthcare provider approval. Drug should never be used in children and teenagers with chickenpox or flu symptoms.
  • Avoid use in late pregnancy as drug may cause premature closure of ductus arteriosus.
  • This drug may cause edema, abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, or angioedema (deep swelling around eyes and lips and sometimes hands and feet).
  • Advise patient to immediately report signs/symptoms of cardiovascular thrombotic events, myocardial infarction, or stroke.
  • Patient should report signs/symptoms of salicylism (tinnitus, vertigo, headache, confusion, drowsiness, sweating, hyperventilation, vomiting, diarrhea).
  • Report signs/symptoms of gastrointestinal hemorrhage, ulceration, or perforation. Elderly and debilitated patients are at higher risk while taking this drug.
  • Patient should also report signs/symptoms of acute renal/hepatic dysfunction, Stevens-Johnson syndrome (flu-like symptoms, spreading red rash, or skin/mucous membrane blistering), or toxic epidermal necrolysis (widespread peeling/blistering of skin).
  • Patient should take drug with food or milk to minimize gastric irritation.
  • Advise patient not to use any other NSAIDs during salsalate therapy unless approved by healthcare professional.
